reviewText:
My recommendation comes with a reservation for those on the fence.

The artwork, story, music, gameplay, comedy and Deponia mythology are all top shelf. In fact it's so well-done I found myself occasionally feeling like the puzzles were a hindrance to the story. If puzzle solving is your primary interest then don't hesitate to buy these games, you should be very satisfied. If you ever feel like puzzles can be a nuisance then do NOT buy these games. If you're somewhere in the middle then buy the games and follow a guide whenever you feel like the pace has become stagnant.

Besides pace I have two more critiques: it doesn't mention in-game you can double click destination arrows to insta-travel. I played for nearly an hour before discovering this. Achievement hunters take note: for better or worse (it's worse) this package bundles all 105 achieves across the 3 games into one set. So you're committed to ~30 hours of gameplay to get to 100%, and that will be for 1 perfect game not three.

Overall I got more than a bargain for my $8 and would love more Deponia story/mythology, but perhaps in another format.

If you're familiar with the genre then you know that this can only mean one thing: MOON LOGIC. You know the drill! This means you have to seduce all three personalities of one lady who all want you to do a different thing and one of them wants a romantic dinner, but the only decent restaurant in town serves disgusting platypus so that needs to go off the menu which means you gotta hatch all these eggs so each kind of platypus will protect their babies and they won't be turned into platypus dinner, but to hatch the eggs you need finish all these minigames, but to even get all that information you need to be a member of the official platypus club and get the official platypus guide for dummies which means you need a membership card, but it can only be found in fortune cookies, but we have no money to order any food and OH MY GOD WE STILL HAVE TO DO THE OTHER TWO OW MY HEAD.

It's pretty bad. The second game is the worst at this as the ridiculousness starts right away while the first and second installment increase the complexity gradually. reviewText:
Short version: 85%If you haven’t bought the Deponia trilogy, the Complete Journey is the best option to experience this famous, not so child-friendly, but in the end quite enjoyable adventure game about a very egotistical protagonist and his struggles to save and/or leave his home planet.

Long version:Deponia: The Complete Journey adds very little to those who already played the trilogy as separate games– it is nothing but a merged version of them. But it is excellent for those who are new to the world of Deponia or want to play the whole story without interruptions (if we don’t count the tutorials, since they were left in there for all three parts).

On the surface, the story is about the struggles of the protagonist, Rufus, and his plans to escape the titular Deponia planet, so he can join the upper society of Elysium. But, looking closer, it is more of a tale of a very egotistical man who uses everyone to his advantage; not because he is evil, but because he honestly thinks he is doing the best for everybody by trying to do the best for himself. The result is not only some slapstick gold, but also excellent dialogues and character synergy between Rufus, his newfound love (Goal from Elysium), and all the others who help them or try to stand in their way.
The characters and the dialogue are the strong points of Deponia, even though the plot suffers from a few problems. It tends to get sidetracked all the time, and as the games progress, the number of plot holes and abandoned story threads increase drastically.

As a point ‘n’ click game, it shows an interesting difficulty curve: it starts off mild, then ramps it up to almost early 90s levels, only to end in some poorly designed or medium level puzzles. This creates a mixed bag for the Complete Edition, but a good bag nonetheless.

reviewText: Wow... Just finished the game. Just wow...\n\nThis game has been tormenting me to finish it from the moment I started playing. I'm not a huge fan of point-and-click adventure games, only because I don't have much experience with them. I've maybe played a few scenes of The Secret of Monkey Island

and I finished the first installment of The Fall. But that's it. So buying this game on sale was sort of my way of trying something new, so take that into consideration.

Well ok then, on to the review.



THE GOOD:

The Art & Sound
The look of the game is phenomenal. It's got a great style and has lots of detail. The music and voice acting are pretty good in my opinion. Most of the music is fairly catchy and atmospheric. The voice talent did a great job, too.

Great Characters and Setting
I really enjoyed the setting and the depth of the characters right away. Whoever was in charge of character development and scripting did a truly phenomenal job! It really added to the overall level of immersion... which brings me to another great point.

Immersive and Thought Provoking Story
From the moment I started playing I was immediately sucked into the world of Deponia: I wanted to know who these people were, who Rufus was and why and how he was trying to get out. This was why I bought the game in the first place: to hear a great story. And the game was certainly great and dramatic and philosophical in its places. And it was the game's great writing that kept me coming back to find out what happens... even when its puzzles frustrated me into a blind rage almost every time I played! Speaking of frustrating...



THE BAD

User Interface
So, I'm not an expert in Point-and-Click type games, but my experience with the UI was incredibly frustrating. The issue I ran into repeatedly was sometimes you could interact with an item from across the map and Rufus would just walk over to it and use it. Other times the item map would say there's an item I could interact with, but I couldn't actually interact with it until I transitioned (via some other item) into a certain area of the scene. It was a little issue, but it cropped up everywhere. And when you're desperate to use your item inventory on *something* and the game doesn't give you the hint to move over a few inches, it really starts to wear on your nerves.


The Puzzles
Because they were such a HUGE annoyance, I break them down into 3 categories:

[::Absurd Puzzles::]
HOLY CRAP the INSANITY! 5 minutes into he game I groaned as I had to find a way to 'lure' my suddenly animated toothbrush out of a dark hole it was hiding it. WTF am I supposed to do with that? I get that I'm new to Point&Click games, but seriously? What sort of logic am I supposed to use to find the answers to these puzzles when they're this absurd? I guess they were supposed to be funny, but when you've been running in circles for an hour looking for an answer, the laughter dries up fast.

[::Obscure Puzzles::]
Often times I found I had to use an object for something completely other than it's typically intended function. Again, earlier in the game there was a loose plank of wood I had to remove, and despite the fact that I had several different objects that would be good for prying it loose, I needed one specific item that one would not normally think to use. There were several times where I was stymied because, despite there was some straightforward problem in front of me and I was fully equipped to deal with it (say, opening a car door?) I had to hunt around for a different item or trigger some obscure chain of events in order to beat it. Which leads me to...

[::Pointless Puzzles and Auto-Fail Puzzles::]
Sometimes you'd go through a total nightmare trying to solve a particular puzzle, only once you finally complete it, the puzzle wasn't narratively important to the story. Or that you failed anyway (despite finishing the puzzle in the game) and are forced to deal with the following consequences. It really undercut the feeling of agency in the game, making it seem like you're just going through the motions until you can get the next snippet of plot.

Which segues perfectly into the next section.


THE UGLY

Rufus the Sociopath
I hated playing as Rufus. Not only do I not like playing as a callous @$$h013, but it actually made the first chapter of the game seem more difficult to complete because no one trusted you. And while I'm sure that was the intent for story purposes and to facilitate creative puzzle solving, it really made it hard to sympathize with the main character. This trend continued for the majority of the game as you single handedly use, abuse and sell out all the other characters around you to get what you want. And just when you think he'll change, he doesn't. But only because the script said so.

reviewText: Deponia is one of the best point'n'clicks I have played in a long time. Its puzzles are reminiscent of the old Monkey Island games, and the humour is without a doubt one of the best of the past 10 years. You play the anti-hero Rufus. As the reviews and intro state, Rufus is not a pleasant man. He's annoying, mean, and absolutely self-centered. The game made me wonder what was wrong with the protagonist several times at the start of the game. He sells women into slavery and feeds children to monsters. And, in spite of all this, he grows on you. He's human. He does horrible things but you still want him to succeed in his plans. Rufus is brilliant, and he's utterly fascinating.\n\nGet this game if you want an interesting protagonist. He won't be your immediate hero. He won't be the man you hope to be, or the man you want your daughter to marry. He's definitely not the man you hope to snag in a relationship. But he will be interesting from start to finish. And that's sorely lacking from games nowadays. So, buy this game and support these makers. You'll be laughing from start to finish.

Deponia started off really well, and then turned into a bit of a disappointment.

The initial story is quite good. You play the bumbling sociopath in his attempt to escape to a new life. Now, some people might find it hard to play a character who makes rather unethical decisions,  but that is the whole point of the game.
It lets the sometimes dark humour flow much more easily and makes for a very enjoyable play through.

However, even though the story started off well, I don't feel it was amazing. Especially towards the end more plot holes started showing, and the actual end of the game was extremely disappointing.
The ending could have been easily solved with a minigame where  you have to find some way of timing everyone to escape from the blades at the same time, and the dev commenter says that they really like minigames. What a missed opportunity that was.
The ending also manages to negate any character development anyone could have had, as all the main characters pretty much have their lives screwed over.

The puzzles in this game are generally pretty good, however in some cases the solutions ended up being extremely obscure and I had to find a walkthrough to prod me in the right direction. This was rather annoying, but for the most part the puzzle, item combination and minigames were designed well.

The interface that goes along with the game has a good menu system, and a good inventory manager. The on-screen hints that show you where clicks are valid is also very helpful.

The graphics in this game are extremely good, as is the soundtrack. It all really adds to the atmosphere and helps makes the exploring the game enjoyable.

reviewText: This is probably one of the best point-and-click adventure games out there. It's actually three games together with a few bonus, but it's a cohesive trilogy. What makes the game interesting is it's humor, present through the whole game, and some very interesting characters. The story is good with some twists even if the ending is a bit disappointing. This edition also includes an interesting Developer's Commentary implemented in-game and a neat questlog. Regarding puzzles, i must say that the game is a bit hard and sometimes the solutions aren't very logical. You'll need to experiment a lot. But it's worth it. If you're a fan of this genre, this is a must buy, except if you own the separate games. If you're new to the genre, maybe this a great way to experiment point-and-click adventures. reviewText:
I grew up playing point-and-click Adventure games, and this game felt like the rightful successor to the Lucas Arts franchises like the Monkey Island games, Day of the Tentacle, etc.  There were some welcome additions like the ability to highlight every interactable object or character on every screen (saving you from having to pixel hunt your way through every puzzle), and an in-game hint system that nudges you in the right direction without spoiling the feeling of solving things for yourself.

The game features a charming story with memorable characters and a solid soundtrack.  The story has some interesting and surprising twists and turns all the way up until the end, and it felt refreshingly un-formulaic.  Some people apparently didn't like that, but I was impressed by the direction the writers took the story in.

I would enthusiastically recommend the game to those looking for a modern twist on a classic genre.  I would also recommend not being put-off by the people whining about the conclusion or complaining about the game not being politically correct 100% of the time.

reviewText:
Great game but for a really poor moral.
Graphics 10
Sound 9 (some samples are louder than others, great music)
Puzzles 10 (managed to solve everything without a walkthrough guide, yet it wasn’t that simple)
Story 8 (some significant plot holes here and there,  too many open ends in the ending for “the complete journey” )
Moral 1
I know, it’s not a common practice to evaluate games by the moral characteristic. But there are way too many disturbing deeds performed by the main character (i.e. by you, as a player). And there are no alternatives – you are forced to do very unpleasant (to say the least) things in order to progress further in game.

I do understand that authors used some kind of dark humor. And while I don’t find every of those dark jokes amusing, I can certainly understand why are those called jokes.
But there are things in this game that I don’t find humorous at all. The most ferocious among them are:
Murder attempt ( locking Gizmo in a burning cabin ),
Killing ( Grandma Utz’s bird, Clever-Byte, Gondolier, baby dolphins ),
Condemning to death ( Goon, Rusty, Gritchen, Hansel ),
Selling into slavery (June) .

Almost every malevolent action is directed against innocent creatures (they aren’t villains and they haven’t done anything harmful to anybody). You just come in and ruin their lives – no apology, no repentance, no nothing.
Every atrocity Rufus commits during the game is reproached only with other people’s “comical” grumbling ( and even justified by Goal in the end ).
And Rufus not only don’t feel any remorse, but also  sarcastically comments his victim’s doom !

The further into the game, the more loathsome things you have to perform.
Goon and June  puzzle was particularly disgusting. I wonder if anyone find this puzzle funny at all. It was the last drop that reversed my impression of the game 180 degrees. Before I solved it I wanted to purchase other Daedalic Entertainment games, but after that – no, thanks.

As far as I can see, the finale is ought to atone Rufus for his sins, but it’s just not enough in terms of moral of the fable – he doesn’t repent of his previous errors, he just let go and goes “hehehe” again.

Don’t let the game’s cartoonish appearance and light-hearted atmosphere deceive you – it is full of dark humor that at times definitely crosses the line of humor, transforming into something sick and repulsive.

For the Deponia and Chaos on Deponia - BRILLIANT. These series are really brilliant. A rare old-school point-and-clicker out there, with a good funny plot, completely worth to play.

For the Goodbye Deponia part: SCREWED. Finally and completely. Just after Rufus gets green chemical to do the culminating thing... it's all screwed up completely. If I could, I would recommend game authors to redo everything just after this moment. Gosh, it will even *sell* again with a different finale!

To clarify: it's not a *BAD* ending. It's *AWFULLY DONE* finale, not only ending, but climax/afterclimax as well. The climax, afterclimax and outcome are all complete, utter and total failures. It leaves you with a complete sense of disappointment, makes the  hours spent in game pointless, and overall tastes awful.

It looks like something's happened in someone's head when team was working on the game at that moment, and completely prevented them from doing anything decent. Game mood is completely ruined after then, and the game ending is quite nonsensical as well, dull and dummy. No ending at all, and no chances for continuation. Be prepared for this when you play the last part of it.

Nevertheless, I would recommend it. It'll give you a decent amount of giggling and laughter.

---

Now for the goodies: what do we have there:

+ Clever tasks and puzzles (almost all are logical, only few are at a point of being foul, and only one thing in Chaos part totally crosses the red line).
+ A lot of toilet humour and slapstick comedy
+ Excellent graphics, decent animation, excellent music
+ Fun, lots of fun
+ Friendly interface, too friendly up to the point it makes game a bit easy (plans and hints) after you're acquainted with it
+ Totally made with love (until the aforementioned third part moment where it's all screwed up).
+ A bit of romance. Although it leaves us to wish for a bit more.
+ Huge diversity of situations.

And for the bad side:

- - - - - - - COMPLETELY SCREWED UP after certain moment in Goodbye. Well, no more about that.
- Too linear a plot. You cannot deviate even a bit, few ways to solve one thing could give player feeling of freedom, and it could took more game time to find all the routes and achievements.
- Some bugs in task and hint tracking system, sometimes it dings when it should not.

For the Deponia and Chaos on Deponia - BRILLIANT. These series are really brilliant. A rare old-school point-and-clicker out there, with a good funny plot, completely worth to play.

For the Goodbye Deponia part: SCREWED. Finally and completely. Just after Rufus gets green chemical to do the culminating thing... it's all screwed up completely. If I could, I would recommend game authors to redo everything just after this moment. Gosh, it will even *sell* again with a different finale!

To clarify: it's not a *BAD* ending. It's *AWFULLY DONE* finale, not only ending, but climax/afterclimax as well. The climax, afterclimax and outcome are all complete, utter and total failures. It leaves you with a complete sense of disappointment, makes the  hours spent in game pointless, and overall tastes awful.

It looks like something's happened in someone's head when team was working on the game at that moment, and completely prevented them from doing anything decent. Game mood is completely ruined after then, and the game ending is quite nonsensical as well, dull and dummy. No ending at all, and no chances for continuation. Be prepared for this when you play the last part of it.

Nevertheless, I would recommend it. It'll give you a decent amount of giggling and laughter.

---

Now for the goodies: what do we have there:

+ Clever tasks and puzzles (almost all are logical, only few are at a point of being foul, and only one thing in Chaos part totally crosses the red line).
+ A lot of toilet humour and slapstick comedy

This is my first review!  I've just been replaying this game after playing through it a few months ago.  The game is fantastic.  It is the best point-click adventure game I've played since Maniac Mansion back on the NES.  The characters are well developed, the play control is intuitive, the logic flow is tricky, but with just enough hints to get through.  The story is seriously clever. The minor play control gripe I have is that the tutorial doesn't tell you that you in fact can skip a lot of the slow walking. If you are moving to a screen you've already been to, you can jump to it (sometimes called zip-mode) by just clicking the orange arrow a couple times.  Also, knowing that the space button reveals all the trigger items is a wonderful feature that, again, should've been in the opening tutorial.

The only serious complaint I have is that the last I checked, you are unable to gift the game.  I tried sending it to a friend only to find that I couldn't...it's weird when you want to hand over money but are unable...

If you like any of the classic Lucasarts or Doublefine games, seriously, just get this. Don't be scared by the fact that it's done by some random German game company you've never heard of. reviewText:
The Deponia trilogy dumps you right onto the surface of the eponymous junkyard planet - several times, usually badly charred and at terminal velocity - puts you into the shoes of our hero Rufus and then expects you to escape its gravity well using your awesome powers of kleptomania, sexism, egoism, general stupidity, the uncanny talent to befriend enemies and alienate friends, McGuyver skills, and an awesome scarf, on your quest to save the world. Just kidding, screw the world, the agenda is to get out of here and hopefully win the affection of some space ladies.

Gameplay-wise, if you have experience with point and click adventures, you have already played this game. The controls are the pinnacle of the genre and its final evolution (disregarding weird experiments like Broken Age's dragging items from the inventory instead of clicking them like a rational human being), complete with a dedicated button to highlight active zones on the screen if you don't feel like pixelhunting. Albeit your pixelhunting skills will prove useful as there are easter eggs that can be collected only by doing so.

The story is certainly interesting, and jumps from old-fashioned slapstick to serious themes, the resulting emotional rollercoaster never failing to give you whiplash. It's got plenty of filler, but the characters are memorable and plotholes few.

It is also a sort of a character study of Rufus, examining his motivations and constantly putting him into the dark to ask what he is. The answer to the question is always the same. What is the answer? You're going to have to find out.

8.5/10

Deponia goes from touching kindness in one scene to ruthless human sacrifices in the other, all performed by the protagnist who is almost, but not quite, likable.

The impression I got from this game was that it was created by a talented team of game developers… and the puerile nephew of their primary financer whom they could not refuse to hire.

Get this game in the bargain bin during the summer or christmas sale though; it certainly has its good points.

reviewText:
An oldschool adventure game with modern graphics. You'll probably love it if you have plenty of nostalgia for the glory days, but as a newcomer, I found the game at best mildly interesting and at worst downright annoying.

The gameplay here is weak due to extremely illogical inventory puzzles that only get worse as you near the end, and thus you essentially have to either spend hours trying every possible combination or read a step-by-step guide. The worst is the second acts of the first two parts, and the last act of the last, as they introduce too many items and too many locations at once, overwhelming you and effectively forcing use of a guide. Minigames, which are rather common, are a welcome change of pace, but are still at times nothing but frustration with little reward.
The story is alright, but unfortunately, you play as the worst (most dishonest, sexist, egotistical, immature, narcissistic, and downright unlikable) character in the game. The humor is awful, due in perhaps no small part to a pretty much literal translation from German, as well as extreme repetition of things that were never funny in the first place.
The visuals are great, and are by far the best part of the game.

Steer clear unless the genre itself is sufficient for you.

Deponia: The Complete Journey is a trilogy of old-school point-and-click adventure games, all wrapped into a single executable file for your convinience.

The story revolves around Rufus, a self-proclaimed genius, a tinkerer, who lives on planet Deponia, covered with trash (Deponie is a German word for garbage landfill). One day, he tries to put into motion another one of his plans to reach Elysium (a spaceship of sorts that is hovering above Deponia and where lives the elite). But (of course) his plan fails again and results in Goal, an Elysian girl, falling down to the surface of Deponia. The rest is about the misadventures of Rufus, Goal, several reccuring characters - how they try to get back to Elysium and what discoveries they make in the process.

I found the jokes in this game to be absolutely hilarious, however that depends on whether you like crass and dark humor or not - there's quite a lot of such humor. And not only the dialogue is funny, the animated sequences contain some funny slapstick situations as well. There are a few (like, a dozen for the whole 30+hrs trilogy) swearwords (which I did not expect), but who cares?

The voice acting (both English and German) is top-notch. I prefer German voiceover, but the English one is just as good - I switched back and forth b/w them a couple of times.

The game is very beautiful, that is if you are willing to overlook low-budget animation drawbacks - sometimes you can feel that there is not enough frames drawn for this or that action to look satisfying. The backgrounds are absolutely gorgeous though.

The puzzles in this game are satisfiyngly difficult, for the most part, which is a good thing. Some of them were, however illogical (like the one with the Yrk and the paper plane, or the one involving the conveyor belt in hell). This is a minor drawback. but still I had to look in the guide a couple of times. For the most part though, the puzzles are creative and you just need to think harder to solve them. A lot of interesting minigames are there as well.

This edition could use some more polish, the game freezed on me a couple of times, which lead to some loss of progress. However not much progress was lost in either case, the game autosaves at important plot points by itself - just make sure to click 'Continue' and not load your last savegame. The text boxes for the commentary sometimes shifts to the right part of the screen, instead of a text box frame. But those are all minor drawbacks, which I am sure will be fixed with a patch.

The community seems to be split about the ending, however I find it brilliant and very cleverly written.

Overall, it's a very enjoyable adventure with a great story, great humor, brilliant plot twists and smart puzzles. I recommend it to any point-and-click adventures enthusiast.

Well, what a journey! I'm a big fan of games with storylines and this is one of the better ones out there. I just finished playing through the story and finished all three parts. Now I have to say that the end is not what I expected but it fits the complete journey well. The only downside is the feels after the end.

The artwork is amazing! Cartoonish and just fun. There is much going on in the scenes but it doesn’t distract you from your story. The story is very well designed. I could relate to some of the characters and parts of the story. Maybe that’s why it’s such a great game for me, but I’m sure that others could have the same experience.

The music and comedy are a big part of the whole experience. It wouldn’t be the same if it wasn’t there or if it would be different. It suits the story, which is a story about love and life. It’s also fun to see that the music is integrated into the world and that characters interact with it.

This game is mostly a point-and-click game but has also a lot of puzzles or mini-games in it. Which can sometimes be a nice change-up from the storyline. If you are a puzzle game fan, you will have a blast with Deponia. If you’re not really into puzzle games, just use the skip button or a guide. I had to use a guide for puzzles one or two times myself.

The game ending is, like I said, not expected. It had a twist which left me with some double feelings. But to know what I mean, you have to play the game from the start and go through the 30+ hours to hopefully get that experience. The end leaves also room for a follow-up, although I doubt that they will make a sequel to the Deponia trilogy.

I’m recommending this game to anyone who loves great storylines in games. No matter what kind of games you normally play. Try this one and play through all three parts. It’s a great game and you’ll love it.

Aesthetically appealing game with developed/adult humour that isn't crass, along with some very clever puzzles and a very engaging storyline. The music works very well. The voice acting is brilliant. The ease of interaction is lovely.

This is a game that will stretch your logic and creativity, whilst having a highly engaging storyline where you can empathise with the main characters throughout, and will not be bored and not often frustrated.

There are some puzzles that require you to be very observant and to really think laterally, but it is not annoying or frustrating, but does feel very rewarding to solve.

When talking about Deponia, it's hard to find a starting point. It's a great point and click with difficult puzzles (too much so for me, although I'm not an experienced PoC player), it's also a great comedy, a brilliant adventure, it does a great job with its protagonist, Rufus, who's something I've never seen in gaming, its rich, post-apocalyptic trash-filled, somewhat steampunk world which allows for a lot of interesting puzzles...

I would hate to spoil you the experience by telling you what's so great about it, and I also can't contain my own impressions and keep a longer review spoiler-free. So here's a pros and cons list, to avoid such jibberish:

Pros:
not completely unique, but fairly engaging story
a lot of difficult puzzles and fun minigames
at least 25h worth of gameplay + developer's commentery for every screen, if you're interested
really good, detailed animation (they don't avoid doing a whole new animation for some little things, just to make them more plausible or funny)
a lot of great comedy at every step in the game
great voice acting
a really unique protagonist
doesn't suffer from RPG syndrome that lets you run so free that you decide your protagonists actions
very dark sense of humor
Cons:
it's fairly linear
puzzles can get really difficult at times, especially in Goodbye Deponia...
...which is partly because they often have ridiculous solutions, to reflect on protagonist's plan-making skillset
the personality of protagonist forces you to do some really, REALLY terrible things and they're the only way to progress
most people dislike the ending for various, often opposite reasons (myself not included)
very dark sense of humor

Oh man, oh man, oh man. What an amazing game. The characters are entertaining, the story is really enjoyable, music is great, and the dialog is perfect in every way.
There are just a few things you should know before buying it:

- All three games took me about 20 hours to beat, and I used a guide when I got stuck. (If you need a guide, I would recommend the GameBoomers walkthroughs) It could take up to double that without a guide and if you aren't very good at point and clicks, as the puzzles can be very tricky.
- I would suggest not using the developer's commentary the first time around, as it doesn't supply any hints and can sometimes give minor spoilers for the scene and / or break the immersion. But, if you have the time, playing the game through a second time and listening to the developer's commentary seems like a pretty good idea. I'm going to be doing it myself when I get the chance.
- It has a good ending, but it definitely won't leave you satisfied.
- It should go without saying, but you should buy the complete journey, or all three individual games if they're on sale and you don't care about the extra content. Each game will just leave you craving to play the next.
- And one last thing - The game never tells you, but you can press the spacebar to show all objects you can interact with in the current scene.

And remember: Hussa - The Chorus-Guys Rule!
